drivers.name: Mike Kirkland

cars.name: Audi Quattro / Sport Quattro / S1 E2
cars.bio: The Audi Quattro family revolutionized rally racing in the 1980s as the first successful four-wheel-drive car in the World Rally Championship, fundamentally altering the landscape of motorsport competition with its groundbreaking drivetrain and turbocharged power.
cars.details_html:
ğŸ Overview

The Audi Quattro debuted in 1980 and changed the face of rallying forever. It was the first car to combine turbocharging with a full-time all-wheel-drive system in top-tier rally competition. This innovation gave Audi an unmatched advantage in traction, particularly on snow, gravel, and loose surfaces. Over the course of the 1980s, the Quattro evolved into the shorter Sport Quattro and the legendary S1 E2 â€” each more radical and powerful than the last. Audi's pioneering AWD concept forced every other manufacturer to rethink rally car design.

The real breakthrough wasnâ€™t just power â€” it was traction. Audi's quattro system provided grip in all conditions, especially in snow and mud, giving them a technological edge over traditional RWD and FWD rivals.

ğŸ† Competitive Highlights

  • 1981 WRC Season: First WRC win at the Swedish Rally with Hannu Mikkola.

  • 1983 WRC Driversâ€™ Champion: Hannu Mikkola wins the title in the Quattro A1/A2.
  • 1984 WRC Sweep: Stig Blomqvist wins Driversâ€™ title; Audi takes the Manufacturersâ€™ championship.
  • 1985 Pikes Peak International Hill Climb: Michele Mouton wins in the S1 E2, setting a new record.

Across the decade, the Quattro secured over 20 WRC victories and forced the end of rear-wheel-drive dominance in rally. Its legacy is deeply rooted in the shift toward AWD rally cars.

ğŸ§  Driving Characteristics

The Quattro was heavy and nose-heavy, especially in early versions, requiring a more measured driving style than the lightweight RWD cars of the time. But its superior traction allowed earlier acceleration out of corners, especially on loose surfaces. As the platform evolved into the S1 E2, it became brutally fast and physically demanding, with extreme turbo lag and monstrous power â€” rewarding aggression, precision, and experience.

ğŸ”§ Legacy & Cultural Impact

The Audi Quattro isnâ€™t just a car â€” itâ€™s a turning point. It ushered in the all-wheel-drive era in rally and inspired future legends like the Lancia Delta Integrale and Subaru Impreza. From snowy Monte Carlo stages to the high-altitude Pikes Peak climb, the Quattro proved itself in every arena. It remains one of the most important cars in motorsport history and a symbol of 1980s rally innovation.

cars.name: Peugeot 205 Turbo 16 / Evo 2

The T16 was nimble, balanced, and exceptionally fast â€” especially in Evo 2 form. Its mid-engine layout gave it excellent handling balance, while the AWD ensured confidence in slippery conditions. The Peugeot 205 Turbo 16 represents the peak of Group B engineering. It not only brought Peugeot back into motorsport prominence but also became a poster child of the era. cars.name: Lancia 037 Rally
cars.bio: The Lancia 037 Rally stood tall as the last rear-wheel-drive car to win the World Rally Championship, using lightweight design, supercharged power, and expert handling to defeat the emerging AWD threat in the early Group B era.

The Lancia 037 Rally made its debut in 1982 as a purpose-built Group B machine. Precise, sharp, and brutally honest â€” the 037 demanded technique and bravery. The Lancia 037 Rally is a symbol of defiance in motorsport history â€” the last RWD champion in an age overtaken by all-wheel drive. cars.name: Lancia Delta S4
cars.bio: The Lancia Delta S4 was a terrifyingly fast Group B machine that pushed the boundaries of rally car design with its twincharged engine, all-wheel drive, and explosive performance, becoming both a legend and a symbol of the categoryâ€™s excess.

Unveiled at the end of 1985, the Lancia Delta S4 was Lanciaâ€™s final entry into Group B â€” and one of the most extreme rally cars ever created. The Delta S4 was capable of beating any car on the grid, but tragedy struck at the 1986 Tour de Corse, when Henri Toivonen and co-driver Sergio Cresto perished in a crash â€” a moment that marked the beginning of the end for Group B.

ğŸ§  Driving Characteristics

Violent, demanding, and unmatched in raw power â€” the Delta S4 was not for the faint of heart. It launched out of corners with savage grip and had so much acceleration that co-drivers often struggled to keep pace. Drivers had to manage turbo lag, sudden power surges, and minimal margin for error. Those who could tame it, like Toivonen, described it as thrilling yet terrifying â€” a machine always on the edge.

ğŸ”§ Legacy & Cultural Impact

The Lancia Delta S4 has become a legend of rally folklore â€” a symbol of both Group Bâ€™s highest peak and its darkest hour. Its insane performance, tragic story, and rarity have made it one of the most revered rally cars of all time. It is remembered as a turning point in the sport, where innovation outpaced safety, and motorsport had to pause and reset.

cars.name: MG Metro 6R4
cars.bio: The MG Metro 6R4 was Britainâ€™s wild card in Group B â€” a naturally aspirated V6, all-wheel-drive machine that stood out for its unique engineering and incredible agility, especially in short, twisty stages and national events.

The 6R4 was known for its razor-sharp handling and immediate engine response. The MG Metro 6R4 is one of the most beloved oddballs of the Group B era. cars.name: Ford RS200
cars.bio: The Ford RS200 was a purpose-built Group B rally car that combined a mid-engine layout, advanced four-wheel drive, and striking design â€” a technical marvel held back by late development and the abrupt end of its era.

The RS200 was one of the most balanced Group B cars ever built. With minimal understeer, quick turn-in, and a perfectly centered engine layout, it felt composed on a wide range of surfaces. However, early models suffered from turbo lag and unpredictable handling at the limit. In the hands of skilled drivers, it was explosively fast â€” but with limited seat time and testing, few could fully extract its potential during its short-lived WRC career.

ğŸ”§ Legacy & Cultural Impact

The Ford RS200 is the quintessential â€˜what if?â€™ car of Group B. Built with vision and cutting-edge engineering, it never had the chance to prove itself on the world stage. Despite this, it remains a fan favorite â€” both for its sleek design and its role in rallying mythology. Today, RS200s are prized in historic motorsport, rallycross, and car collections, where they continue to thrill with a mix of precision, rawness, and unfulfilled destiny.

cars.name: Renault 5 Turbo / Turbo 2

The Renault 5 Turbo was tail-happy, twitchy, and incredibly fun â€” but also unforgiving. The Renault 5 Turbo has become a cult classic â€” a poster child for creative engineering in the golden era of rallying. Revered by fans and feared by competitors on tarmac, the 5 Turbo is one of the most celebrated rally cars of the early 1980s.

cars.name: Opel Ascona 400

The Ascona 400 required finesse and patience. It was a momentum car â€” best when driven smoothly with precise inputs. Though not flashy, it rewarded technical excellence and consistency over brute force.

ğŸ”§ Legacy & Cultural Impact

The Opel Ascona 400 is remembered as the last of a dying breed â€” a RWD rally champion standing tall just before Group B changed the game. Today, it holds legendary status among fans of analog, driver-focused rally machines from the sportâ€™s transitional golden age.

cars.name: Fiat 131 Abarth

Even as Group B machines were in development, the 131 Abarth remained a reliable, quick, and rally-proven option â€” particularly in events where endurance and robustness mattered more than outright speed.
